I personally enjoy shooting with my iPhone 7 because that’s what I have at hand right now. However, I would love to test out the new pixel phone. The best camera phone will always be the one that you carry with you. It’s the photographer who creates the great image, the camera phone merely record the capture. These are shot and edited on an iPhone 7:

Your statement is incorrect. iPhone smartphone cameras are not the “best” when tested by the experts at DXOMARK. However they are good, and easy to use, and the camera doesn’t make many mistakes. If the photos look better to your eyes, I can’t argue that point. However, I’ve got an old $200 point and shoot camera that will blow every smartphone camera out of the water. In my opinion, all this quibbling and discussions about which smartphone camera is better is a huge time waster. If you want pretty pictures, buy a real camera. If you want to fuck around with a selfie stick, keep your smartphone.

Actually, Samsung phones generally make better photos. But, anyway, the “MP” of a camera only determines how big you can print the photos - not how good they will look. If you’re not printing, it’s pretty much an irrelevant metric. The quality of the photos is determined mostly by the lens and the post processing (but those things can’t be expressed by a single number, so they’re not mentioned in advertising materials).
Because the Megapixels is NOT the only factor in cameras. There’s also Aperture. Field of View, Focus and many more.
